citations.narrative:
A total of 5 puppies under 16 weeks of age and 3 dogs over 16 weeks of age did not have official identification as required
by the Animal Welfare Act. In one enclosure, 5 puppies under 16 weeks of age were present without their dam. They were
identified by a cage card but had not received official identification after being weaned and removed from their mother.
Another 2 dogs, older than 16 weeks, were present in the same cage also without official identification (only documented
on a cage card). In another kennel, a newly acquired puppy under 16 weeks of age did not have official identification, only
identified by name. Official identification for all dogs under 16 weeks of age and separated from their dam and all dogs
over 16 weeks of age is important to trace the movement of animals and account for those present on the property.
Correct by June 2, 2023 by ensuring all puppies under 16 weeks of age separated from their dam and all dogs over 16
weeks of age have a form of official identification such as an official tag, tattoo approved by the administrator, or
microchip.

The facility does not have a comprehensive written contingency plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment,
transportation, housing, or care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. If an emergency or natural
disaster were to occur at the facility, the lack of a complete written contingency plan could impact animal health if staff are
not prepared to respond to the situation appropriately. Correct by June 2, 2023 by developing, documenting, and following
an appropriate contingency plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their
animals in the the event of an emergency or disaster.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
